The market sell-off showed little signs of applying the brakes in the dying minutes of Tuesday's session. Banking, biotech and select metals firms including steel production and metal ores led the decline.With minutes left in the session, the Nasdaq composite accelerated its drop in the final hour of trading, falling 1.8% as large and megacap techs retreated. It's clearly going to be the Nasdaq's biggest single-session drop since the Nov. 8 U.S. elections.The S&P 500 was down nearly 1%. The Dow Jones industrial average provided no relief as it too fell more than 0.9%. Volume expanded sharply vs. Monday, meaning that it is likely to be a true distribution day, or session of intense professional selling.A spate of four or five such distribution days is enough to end a bull market, or at the minimum trigger a mild correction in the range of 5% to 10%.Small caps took bigger hits as the Russell 2000 fell more than 2.6% and dipped back into slightly negative ground for the year. In 2016, the popular small-cap equity index rallied 19.5%. Major Wall Street banks sold off on growing concern about what impact Britain's future exit from the eurozone will have on London's status as a major banking center.Goldman Sachs (GS), which announced that it will move hundreds of employees out of the United Kingdom capital in preparation for the changes, dropped 8.32 points, or more than 3%, and slumped sharply below its 50-day moving average. Volume was running about 26% above average levels.The Wall Street bank, which has thrived by recent movement in U.S. Treasury bonds, is triggering its first major sell signal since breaking out of a long first-stage base with a 172.52 buy point in late October. The gain reached as high as 48%, big enough to have justified taking profits on the way up.One could decide to sell at least half a position bought at the proper entry, then see if the Dow Jones industrials component can rebound back to its 50-day line. For now, shares are trading less than 9% below the 255.15 high.Fellow money-center banks — Bank of Montreal (BMO) and Royal Bank of Canada (RY), as well as Morgan Stanley (MS) — are also down between 0.5% and 4% and showing weak action near their respective 50-day lines. Superregional lender SVB Financial (SIVB) took out its 50-day moving average for the first time since its early October breakout from a large bottoming-style base. Shares in the Santa Clara, Calif., firm slumped more than 6% to 175.84 in more than double average trade. At its 198.83 peak, SVB rose as much as 76% from the 112.93 handle entry.Also in IBD's superregional bank industry group, Dallas-based Comerica (CMA) and SunTrust Banks (STI) of Atlanta dropped more than 5% in heavy turnover and triggered the 50-day line sell rule.Phoenix-based Western Alliance Bancorp (WAL), a top-rated company in IBD's West/Southwest bank group, got slammed with a 7% drop to 47.05, also sinking below its 50-day line in volume running nearly four times usual levels.The stock also triggered the golden rule of selling by falling more than 7% below a recent new flat base entry at 50.82.IBD 50 stocks were not immune to the blanket-like sell-off.China's top internet video game firm NetEase (NTES) slid nearly 4% to 282.59. Yet for now, the stock is holding above its fast-rising 50-day moving average and keeping the air pocket created by an earnings-inspired Feb. 16 big gap up in price. The stock is also still extended more than 5% past a 257.78 cup-with-handle entry point.Cognex (CGNX) and Veeva Systems (VEEV) both fell more than 2% in heavy trading. The former has already gained more than 50% since clearing a 53.55 flat-base entry, while the latter pulled back near a 48.05 flat-base buy point. Yet Veeva has also risen significantly since it broke out of a first-stage bottoming base pattern at 28.05 in May 2016.Keeping gains by selling at least half the position after the rally has exceeded 20% to 25% is a smart portfolio management technique for your growth stocks.On the upside, Wynn Resorts (WYNN) is staging an eighth straight up-day, rising 1% to 112.93. That pushed the gaming resort operator's advance to 8% past a 104.49 buy point, in a choppy cup-with-handle base — so shares are extended. Wynn has large operations in Macau, the island territory of China where casino gambling is legalized. Wall Street sees full-year profit rising 27% to $4.29 a share in 2017, then up another 16% to $4.99 in 2018.RELATED:Stock Market Today: Should You Sell These 7 Dow-30 Stocks?When To Sell A Stock: Take Profits When 2 Or More Key Rules Get TriggeredWhen To Sell A Stock II: Use The 50-Day Moving Average As A Guide

XFutures for the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq 100 fell slightly in Sunday evening trading. Dow futures edged down 0.1% while S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 futures dipped 0.2%.The major averages all rose slightly in the past week, with the Nasdaq composite briefly setting an all-time high on Friday.But JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS), both Dow industrials components, retreated last week, along with Bank of America (BAC), Citigroup (C), Morgan Stanley (MS) and a slew of other banks. Several bank stocks, notably Goldman and Morgan Stanley, are testing their 50-day moving averages.The Federal Reserve's decision not to signal faster interest rate hikes after Wednesday's expected quarter-point increase buoyed most stocks. But banks sold off as Treasury yields fell, especially at the high end. Lower yields and a flatter curve between short- and long-term maturities hurts banks' borrow short, lend long profit model.IBD'S TAKE: Financial stocks often are sensitive to interest rates swings, but not all: Here's a big-cap financial stock that in buy range now.JPMorgan, which gapped up at the beginning of March as investors priced in the March 15 Fed hike, fell about 1% in Friday stock market trading, essentially at its lowest levels of the month, but still not too close to its rising 50-day line.Fellow Dow stock Goldman Sachs sank 1.7% to 243.92 on Friday, closing just above its 50-day line. So did the other big pure-play investment bank Morgan Stanley, which retreated 2.8% Friday.Bank of America sank 1.4% on Friday, but is comfortably above its 50-day line. BofA tested its 50-day in early February, then had a solid advance through March 1.Citigroup, which was one of the few big banks to trade below its 50-day line earlier this year, fell 1.3% to 60.37 on Friday. Citigroup crossed a 61.73 buy point several times this month, but never closed above that level.PNC Financial (PNC) is approaching its 50-day line, Regions Financial (RF) briefly undercut that level on Friday, while BB&T Corp. (BBT), Keycorp (KEY) and Suntrust Financial (STI) all closed the week below that support area.Keep in mind that in most of these cases, the stock are not far multi-year highs.In Asian Monday intraday, Hong Kong's Hang Seng index rose to its best levels since 2015. Stocks also edged higher in China, while falling in Australia and South Korea. Japan's Nikkei was closed for Monday.RELATED:These Are The 5 Biggest S&P 500 Stocks In Buy Range NowThe Big Picture: 5 Dow Stocks Are Near Buy Points

The rally in regional banks has moderated, but two ETFs that track the industry are using that pause to refresh their charts.The charts of SPDR S&P Regional Banking (KRE) and iShares U.S. Regional Banks (IAT) look like twins, the way they've behaved so similarly. Both have pulled back from highs reached at the start of March and are testing the 50-day moving average.With a bit more of a bounce, both exchange traded funds will be in buy areas. At the moment, the support at the 50-day line is not convincing enough. Watch for shares of both to climb at least one more point, and preferably in above-average volume.No chart reader would dispute that both ETFs were in need of a break. They shot up starting in mid-November on a combination of rising interest rates and President Trump's election. Trump and Republicans are trying to ease banking regulations, and higher rates are widening interest margins for banks.While SPDR Regional Banking has 100 stocks, iShares Regional Banks has about half as many.Still, the two portfolios are similar in terms of the largest holdings. PNC Financial Services (PNC), SunTrust Bank (STI), M&T Bank (MTB), Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB), Huntington Bancshares (HBAN), KeyCorp (KEY), Regions Financial (RF), Citizens Financial (CFG) and BB&T (BBT) are top-10 holdings in both funds.The two differ in that iShares Regional Banks has a big stake in U.S. Bancorp (USB) (more than 16% of the portfolio) while the superregional bank doesn't even make the SPDR Regional Banking portfolio.The holdings of SPDR Regional Banking are more spread out, with no single stock accounting for more than 4% of the total weighting.With the Federal Reserve expected to increase interest rates by a quarter-point two more times this year, the fundamental backdrop for regional banks is generally favorable. Higher rates tend to widen the margin between interest earned on loans vs. interest paid on deposits.LPL Financial, for example, had this to say: "Steepening yield curve, deregulation, expanded credit access, strong fourth quarter 2016 earnings, and positive revisions are all supportive."But Alastair George, chief strategist at Edison Investment Research, saw an economic warning sign in the banking sector. "In the U.S., bank loan growth has slowed significantly since Q4 and the Atlanta Fed's GDP nowcast is only indicating 1.2% U.S. growth for the current quarter, compared to over 2.5% as recently as early February." The IBD ETF Leaders index shows the performance of a model portfolio of exchange traded funds that are leading the overall market. A computer algorithm selects the ETFs based on relative strength and other objective performance ratings, with periodic adjustments for market trends and conditions. The universe from which the ETFs are selected includes the funds listed below.RELATED:Chip ETF In Buy Area As Sector Continues To Lead

The country's best-performing stock mutual funds in the past three months continued to stock up on banks, financials, and chips stocks in their latest reporting periods.Building issues, such as Thor Industries (THO), Eagle Materials (EXP), Apogee Enterprises (APOG) and Trex (TREX) have been performing well. Construction stocks may benefit from President Trump's plans to ramp up infrastructure projects and build a wall along the U.S.-Mexican border.A handful of chips stocks consistently show up on the new buys list, including Advanced Energy Industries (AEIS), Inphi (IPHI), Applied Materials (AMAT) and Nvidia (NVDA), which boasts an estimated $449 million invested by 46 top-notch funds. Internet stocks GrubHub (GRUB) and LogMeIn (LOGM) were also favorites among elite money managers.As the stock market continued to ride the waves of Trump rally in January, banks have been basking in the glory of rising rates. Forty-three leading funds added big bank Morgan Stanley (MS), investing an estimated $402 million. Investors also like regional banks, such as Citizens Financial Group (CFG), SVB Financial Group (SIVB) and  Zions Bancorp (ZION).Financial investment banks and brokers Evercore Partners (EVR), Raymond James Financial (RJF) and E-Trade Financial (ETFC) were solid performers.IBD noted 20 top-performing funds buying GrubHub, investing an estimated $27 million in their latest reporting periods. The $2.5 billion Alger Capital Appreciation Fund (ACAAX) owned a small stake in the firm.The online mobile food-ordering firm makes it easy for hungry diners to order food delivery from its mobile app. The Chicago-based company continues to add more restaurants to their offering, giving diners more options, thus driving growth.The company will announce fourth-quarter earnings on Feb. 8.Since hitting a 52-week high at the end of September, GrubHub has been working on the right side of a shallow consolidation. It's currently sitting just 7% off its high. Read more GrubHub on IBD Stock Analysis on page B8 and last week's New America on page A20.While banks were being bought by top funds overall, it's not unusual to see some profit-taking by the nation's top funds as well. JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Regions Financial (RF), US Bancorp (USB), M&T Bank (MTB) and SunTrust Banks (STI), which have hit recent 52-week highs, were among the latest sells by top-performing funds.RELATED:Top Tech Stock Caters To Hungry Diners, Investors

U.S. stock indexes chalked up losses in midday action Tuesday, as small caps and bank stocks led the way down.The small-cap Russell 2000 and tech-leaning Nasdaq dropped 0.9% and 0.4%, respectively. The S&P 500 and the blue chip Dow Jones industrial average held up better, each shaving off 0.2%. Volume in the stock market today was running sharply higher on both major exchanges.Small caps and bank stocks have been two hot areas in the postelection rally. However, they came in for some apparent profit-taking today. Meanwhile, some blue chips were holding up well.Home Depot (HD), a Dow Jones industrial average component, popped 1.27 to 136.31. The stock has shaped a saucer with handle with a potential buy point at 137.42. The pattern is first stage, which is more likely to work than later bases.Home Depot's fiscal year ends in January. The Street expects 2017 earnings to rise 18%, which represents an upward revision. Q4 results will be released Feb. 21.Procter & Gamble (PG), another Dow component, advanced 1.21 to 85.22 in brisk volume. The megacap retook its 50-day and 200-day lines. Procter & Gamble is working on a flat base but has some work to do on the right side of its pattern. The base is first stage.In the S&P 500, superregional bank Comerica (CMA) took the hardest hit, gapping down 3.83 to 66.09. Volume was heavy. The company reported quarterly results, topping the earnings target by about 14%. Revenue was lower than expected.IBD'S TAKE: Don't ignore tobacco stocks. Two have outperformed the major indexes for three years in a row.Morgan Stanley (MS) also reported. The money center beat the Street's consensus estimate by about 25%. But the stock dropped 1.24 to 42.58.Other banks reporting this week include Citigroup (C), Goldman Sachs (GS), U.S. Bancorp (USB) and Northern Trust (NTRS), which all report Wednesday. All four were down in midday trade Tuesday.On Thursday, KeyCorp (KEY), SunTrust Banks (STI) and Home BancShares (HOMB) will report. These bank stocks also were down Tuesday.The banks were among the top performers since Election Day but appear to be undergoing some profit-taking. President-elect Donald Trump's negative comments about the strong dollar and the House GOP border-adjustment tax hit financials.Oil prices rose as Saudi Arabia affirmed its previous pledge to cut output. The U.S. oil explorers group rose on the news, but much of the group action was tied to acquisitions.Texas-based Clayton Williams Energy (CWEI) gapped up 37% in monster volume. On Monday, Noble Energy (NBL) announced it would acquire Clayton. Noble was up 7%.Sanchez Energy (SN) added 16% after jumping 29% Friday. On Thursday, Anadarko Petroleum (APC) announced it would sell its Eagleford shale assets to a joint venture that includes Sanchez Energy.RELATED:Trump's Doubts On GOP Tax Plan Help Sink Banks; Morgan Stanley TopsBritish American Tobacco, Reynolds American Agree On $49 Billion MergerMay Pledges U.K. Parliament Vote On Leaving EU Single Market; Pound SoarsNoble Pays $2.7 Billion For Clayton Williams In Permian Basin DealExxon Doubles Stake In Permian BasinArista Dives 9% On Setback in Cisco Legal Battle

Loading the player... The Nasdaq got back on track Friday, a day after posting its first down day of 2017. Small caps also recovered, with the S&P 600 rising 0.8% after falling in four of the previous eight sessions, the only ones so far this new year. On Friday, the Nasdaq gained 0.5%, while the S&P 500 added 0.2% and…

U.S. stock indexes advanced nicely Tuesday, but volume stepped down markedly.The Nasdaq rose 1.1%, while the S&P 500 added 0.7%. The blue chip Dow Jones industrial average crawled 0.3% higher. Small caps, which have been leading the market of late, tacked on 0.3% in the S&P 600. Volume in the stock market today declined roughly 15% on the NYSE and 10% on the Nasdaq from the previous session's pace, according to preliminary figures.Follow-up action has been rather weak among the major indexes, but small caps and select sectors have done very well. Bulls would like to see some days of big gains in rising volume.Banks have been the star sector recently. On Monday, 153 banks scored new highs while the two major indexes accounted for 751 new highs. Nine bank stocks now make up about half of the Big Cap 20, which is a list of the best big caps by fundamentals and technicals. On Tuesday, bank winners led losers in the Big Cap 20.Big Cap 20 members Morgan Stanley (MS), Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB), KeyCorp (KEY) and Regions Financial (RF) each rose more than 1%, according to preliminary data. Goldman Sachs (GS), Citizens Financial Bank (CFG) and SunTrust Banks (STI) scored smaller gains. M & T Bank (MTB) lost ground.The construction aggregates and cement stocks also have been leaders. But Tuesday, they were taking a timeout. Martin Marietta Materials (MLM), Vulcan Materials (VMC) and Eagle Materials (EXP) recorded losses but without damaging the overall bullishness of their chart patterns.Meanwhile, economic news was mostly positive.Retail sales for October were stronger than expected, and September results were revised upward. The Street expected a 0.6% pop in October, but the percentage came in at 0.8% — above the highest estimate in the range. The September figure initially was reported at 0.6% but was revised to 1%.Most stocks in the retail sector are currently laggards. Of the 18 groups in the retail sector, roughly two-thirds are in the bottom half among 197 industry groups. The one highly rated group is department stores, which is No. 8.Manufacturing also topped expectations. The Empire State manufacturing gauge for November rose 1.5, also above the highest estimate in the range, according to Econoday. The Street expected a reading of minus 2.3. November marked the first positive reading since July.Business inventories for September inched up 0.1%, falling shy of views for 0.2%.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, oil stocks and gold miners were the day's biggest gainers. On the downside, retail held most of the biggest losses.RELATED:What's Happening Under The Hood In Retail?Oil Rallies The Most In 7 Weeks: Here's Why

Needham & Co. upgraded chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA) to buy, Morgan Stanley upgraded United States Steel (X) as well as Citigroup (C) amid potential upside from President-elect Donald Trump's political agenda, and Pacific Crest Securities upgraded payment processor Square (SQ) to overweight.Needham & Co. upgraded Nvidia, which tops the IBD 50 list of growth stocks, to buy with a price target of 100. Nvidia stock spiked nearly 30% Friday to a record high after crushing Wall Street's fiscal third-quarter sales and earnings estimates and guiding higher for the current quarter.Shares retreated 4.9% to 83.64 on the stock market today.RELATED:Nvidia Stock Soars To Record High On 'Blowout' Earnings, Raised GuidanceNvidia, Intel Battleground Set As Licensing Pact SunsetsMorgan Stanley upgraded Citigroup to overweight and State Street (STT) to equal weight. Citi's price target was also raised to 70 from 50. Bank stocks have rallied on hopes that the incoming Trump administration will dismantle the 2010 Dodd-Frank bank regulations. But Morgan Stanley downgraded SunTrust Bank (STI) and U.S. Bancorp (USB) to underweight.Shares of Citigroup were up 3.5% at 54.68 Monday.Morgan Stanley upgraded U.S. Steel to overweight with a price target of 46 and AK Steel (AKS) to overweight with a price target of 11. Trump's trade policies are expected to benefit domestic steel producers.Shares of U.S. Steel jumped 8% to 27.78, closing just above a 27.74 buy point. AK Steel leapt 10.4% to 8.28, heading for profit-taking territory.RELATED:Steel Stocks Soar As Trump Seen Fueling 20% Annual Demand GrowthSteel Dynamics: On A Roll As Steel Hints At Inflection PointPacific Crest upgraded payment processor Square to overweight with a price target of 15. Analyst Josh Beck expects free cash flow to grow. "As we move through 2017, we believe Square may more consistently provide positive fundamental surprises," Beck said in a report.Shares rose 4% to 12.35.Stifel upgraded online takeout website GrubHub (GRUB) to buy with a price target of 46. GrubHub shares have fallen by over 20% since reaching a 52-week high of nearly $45 in late September. Shares fell about 5% to 35.31 on Friday amid media reports that its CEO sent a letter to employees speaking out against Trump supporters.On Monday, shares rose 2.9% to 36.34.In other analyst moves, Stifel upgraded Lockheed Martin (LMT) to buy with a price target of 290. Stifel initiated Sage Therapeutics (SAGE) at buy with a price target of 90; Stifel started Gilead Sciences (GILD) also at buy with a price target of 100. Deutsche Bank upgraded Ciena (CIEN) to buy. IBD's Telecom Fiber-Optics group is ranked No. 3 out of 197 industry groups. Several brokerages initiated coverage on Forterra (FRTA), a water infrastructure provider that went public at 18 on Oct. 21. Citigroup and RBC Capital have buy ratings, while Goldman Sachs, Deutsche Bank and Credit Suisse started coverage at neutral.IBD'S TAKE: Investors should keep a watchlist of top-rated stocks forming bullish patterns. With the market rebounding, check out IBD's new feature, Stocks Near A Buy Zone.RELATED:Apple, Microsoft, Citigroup Retake Buy Points As Market Rallies

The major indexes continued to yo-yo back and forth with an hour left in Thursday's session. But small caps continued to sell off hard.The Russell 2000 dropped more than 1%, topping a 0.9% slide on Wednesday. In contrast, the Dow Jones industrials poked slightly lower despite solid gains by components such as IBM (IBM), DuPont (DD) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ).DuPont, up 1.8% to 69.89, is approaching a cup with long handle entry at 71.19, which is not far below the cup's left-side high of 75.72.The S&P 500 was off a bit more than 0.1%. The Nasdaq fell 0.5%. But the S&P 100, which houses the 100 largest firms by market cap, was up slightly. Volume was running more than 10% higher on both the Nasdaq and the NYSE vs. the same time Wednesday.While real estate-related plays slumped in the stock market today, banks attracted more buying as the yield on the U.S. 10-year Treasury bond rose to almost 1.85%. Higher interest rates generally enable lenders to expand their profit margins in loan products.Wall Street giant JPMorgan Chase (JPM), another Dow 30 component, rose nearly 0.8% to 69.57 in dull volume. The stock continues to rise further past a 65.08 buy point in a narrow cup with handle pattern, built within a much larger base structure. An investor could have also bought shares when JPMorgan cleared a secondary handle at 66.58. From that second buy point, the 5% permissible buy zone extends up to 69.91.JPMorgan rival Morgan Stanley (MS) was up nearly 1% to 33.89, rising nearly 3% past a 32.47 entry in a bottoming-style cup with handle base.Super-regionals are also rallying. SunTrust (STI) of Atlanta rallied nearly 1% to 45.97, up more than 3% past a cup with long handle entry at 44.42, before easing some. The 5% chase zone goes up to 46.64.SunTrust, which last week reported another quarter of single-digit top and bottom-line growth, boasts ultrareliable profitability and a 2.3% annualized dividend, better than the S&P 500's 2.11% yield as of Wednesday's close.SunTrust scores an excellent three-year Earnings Stability Factor of 3 on a scale of zero (stable) to 99 (wild). Steady profits give corporate boards the confidence to raise or maintain cash payouts to shareholders.IBD's super-regional banking group is up 1.2% so far in the stock market today. Also pacing the upside were the ship transport, trucking, water supply utility, education and dairy products industry groups, each up 1% or more.IBD'S TAKE: The cup with handle base is one of the most important chart patterns that an investor can learn to time their buys of great stocks. For the basics, take this free online course at IBD University.RELATED:How To Spot The Cup With Handle, A Winning Pattern For Growth InvestorsSee The Sector Rotation: Money Moves Into Defense FirmsWhat Is The Bottoming Base Pattern?

After a period when failed breakouts were plentiful, stocks are showing renewed strength as market indexes recover from the recent shallow pullback. SunTrust (STI) hit new highs Wednesday, another day of positive gains in heavier volume. The stock was up nearly 2% to close at 46.21 on Wednesday, extending gains from Oct. 4, when the stock broke out from a flat base…

The major averages gave up their intraday gains to close back in the red Thursday, as sliding oil prices, weak economic data and mixed earnings reports weighed.The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.2%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq eased 0.1% each. Volume was mixed; slightly lower on the NYSE but higher on the Nasdaq, according to preliminary figures.Tool makers, drugstores and steel stocks led the upside in the stock market today. Snap-On (SNA) gapped up and surged 7%, retaking its 50-day and 200-day lines in heavy trade. The hand and power tools maker reported mixed Q3 results as earnings topped but sales missed estimates.Walgreens Boots Alliance (WBA) leapt 5% in healthy volume, regaining its 200-day line but stopping just short of its 50-day line. The drugstore operator's fiscal Q4 profit beat views, but revenue missed. It also extended its merger deadline with Rite Aid (RAD) as it seeks regulatory approval for the deal. Walgreens announced plans last year to acquire Rite Aid for $17.2 billion. Rite-Aid vaulted 7% Thursday.American Express (AXP) was the Dow's biggest winner, up 9% in heavy volume. Shares gapped up past the 50-day and 200-day moving average lines to their highest level in over nine months. The credit card provider reported strong earnings after the close Wednesday.Microsoft (MSFT) jumped 5% after the close on better-than-expected fiscal Q1 results. The Xbox and Surface maker's stock closed the regular session with a 0.5% loss as it works on a flat base with a 58.80 buy point.The biggest blue chip loser was Travelers (TRV), down 6% in heavy trade to its lowest close since late April. The insurance giant reported Q3 profit that fell 18% from last year and missed views.EBay (EBAY) gapped down and tumbled 11% after reporting Q3 results that topped forecasts but Q5 revenue guidance that disappointed. The stock triggered a sell rule as it wiped out an 11% gain from a 29.93 buy point cleared in July. It's now 3% below the entry.In economic news, weekly jobless claims rose 5% to 260,000, above expectations for 250,000 claims. The Philly Fed business outlook survey for October came in at 9.7, down from September's 12.8 reading.A light economic data schedule Friday includes Baker-Hughes' weekly rig count. The Fed's Daniel Tarullo and John Williams are also slated to speak.Earnings reports are due from General Electric (GE), Honeywell (HON), McDonald's (MCD) and SunTrust Banks (STI).RELATED:Walgreens Boots Alliance Earnings Mixed; Rite Aid Deadline ExtendedEBay Gets Picked Apart As Q3 Earnings Miss Some Key Metrics

Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) have broken out this week on growing Federal Reserve rate-hike speculation and relief over Deutsche Bank (DB).After AFP reported that Deutsche Bank could settle a mortgage-securities case for far less than the Justice Department asked for, potentially warding off a bigger shock to the global banking industry, Bank of America and Citigroup on Friday bounced off their 50-day lines. Meanwhile, Fed officials' comments and recent economic data have reinforced expectations for central bank tightening by the end of the year.Banks and bank stocks should do well if the Fed raises rates because it allow them to increase the spread between its lending rates and borrowing costs. Banks' net interest margins have been squeezed in recent years.JPMorgan Chase (JPM), meanwhile, also rebounded off its 50-day. JPMorgan broke out in early August from a handle in a consolidation and remains within range of the 66.58 buy point. JPMorgan rose 1.6% to 67.69 Wednesday.Citigroup climbed 1.9% to 48.65 in the stock market today, hitting its best levels since early January. Citigroup cleared a 48.28 buy point in an 11-month consolidation.Bank of America advanced 2.% to 16.11. BofA is 4.9% above its 50-day line, still within the chase zone. Ideally, for a stock to be within buy range, it should be no more than 5% above the 50-day line.Wells Fargo rose 2.8%, but from a two-and-a-half-year low. Wells Fargo is still reeling from the cross-selling scandal.IBD'S TAKE: The Banks-Money Center industry group, which includes the big banks, moves in tandem with the Federal Reserve's announcements on interest rates. To learn more about top industry groups and taking profits quickly rapid changes in the market, see this story about Swing Trading strategies. Meanwhile, some super-regional banks also have broken out. SunTrust Banks (STI) broke past a 44.71 buy point of a consolidation pattern begun in late May on Tuesday. On Wednesday, SunTrust rose 2.2% to 45.73, still in range. SunTrust had found resistance several times just above 44 in recent months.Meanwhile, Comerica (CMA) rose 2.8% to 49.21 Wednesday, extended from buy range but still performing solidly.Wednesday's bank stock gains come as ADP reported that companies added 154,000 jobs in September, short of estimates for 170,000 but still solid. Meanwhile, the ISM nonmanufacturing index shot up to an 11-month high last month. On Monday, ISM's manufacturing index signaled a return to factory expansion.RELATED:New High Analysis: Session Yields Slew Of Financial BreakoutsU.S. Banking Giants Gain As Deutsche Bank, European Financials TeeterBank Of America Gains Share Globally, Vows Blockchain EmbraceJPMorgan, Goldman, Citi Waver As Rates To Stay Lower For Longer

Banks retreated Thursday, testing buy points as Treasury yields fell ahead of earnings from Citigroup (C), Wells Fargo (WFC) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) out Friday.Treasury yields were down Thursday after a weaker-than-expected trade report out of China sent investors toward government bonds and other safe assets. Investors have bid financials in recent weeks on the prospect of Federal Reserve rate hikes and the recent rise of long-term yields around the world. JPMorgan fell 0.6% to 67.74 on the stock market today after dropping as low as 66.82, just above the 50-day line. The stock is still in range from a buy point of 65.08, cleared in early August.JPMorgan is expected to report a 17% drop in third-quarter earnings but revenue is seen rising 2% to $23.988 billion when it announces quarterly results Friday.Citigroup shares dipped 0.5% to 48.47 after sinking intraday to 47.54, below a recent 48.24 buy point. Analysts see Citi's Q3 EPS falling 15% on Friday to $1.15, with revenue down 6% to $17.344 billion. Wells Fargo shares slid 1.3% to 44.75 well below its 50-day and 200-day lines. The bank has its own issues after a Consumer Financial Protection Bureau review found employees may have opened more than 2 million accounts and credit cards without consumers' permission. Late Wednesday, Wells said CEO John Stumpf stepped down, effective immediately, replaced by President and COO Tim Sloan.Bank of America (BAC) is slated to report results Monday, Goldman Sachs (GS) Tuesday, and Morgan Stanley (MS) on Wednesday. BofA shares fell 1.25%, continuing a recent slide after peeking into buy range on Monday. Goldman lost 1.1% and Morgan Stanley 0.6%.IBD'S TAKE: U.K.'s Brexit, bad loans at Italian banks and legal troubles from Germany's Deutsche Bank have opened the European market to U.S. banks. Regional banks, more directly dependent of lending than global Wall Street banks, were also under pressure Thursday.Comerica (CMA) shares fell 1.4% to 47.91, still in buy range, with a 46.40 buy point, out of a cup with handle base but falling toward its 50-day line.SunTrust Banks (STI) shares tumbled 2.1% to 44.76 falling toward its 50-day line but still in buy range, above its buy point of 44.42, after consolidating out of a flat base.Regions Financial (RF) stock fell 2.8% to 9.95, finding support at its 50-day line and off session lows of 9.78, but below its buy point of 10.10.RELATED:Bank Of America Gains Share Globally, Vows Blockchain Embrace

Smith (AOS), LGI Homes (LGIH) and Central Garden & Pet (CENTA) were some of the defensive names top funds were buying in their latest reporting periods.Other industrial-materials stocks that were looking good included metal fabricators Gibraltar Industries (ROCK) and Worthington Industries (WOR).Top funds held a big stake in Chinese internet retail giant Alibaba Group (BABA). Bank stocks are holding up relatively well amid a sharp market sell-off Friday as more Federal Reserve officials prime the U.S. for a potential interest-rate hike. But JPMorgan Chase (JPM) remained the only big-bank stock within buy range as of Friday afternoon.JPMorgan Chase fell 0.9% to close at 66.65 in the stock market today, as it was downgraded on Friday by Macquarie Research. But it's still above a 65.08 buy point cleared in early August from a handle in a consolidation.Boston Fed President Eric Rosengren said Friday that waiting too long to raise rates could damage the economy."My personal view, based on economic data that we have received to date, is that a reasonable case can be made for continuing to pursue a gradual normalization of monetary policy," Rosengren said to the South Shore Chamber of Commerce, Quincy, Mass.Several other policymakers have made similar comments. But Rosengren had long been considered a policy dove. His comments raised the odds of a September-meeting rate hike, but most investors see the next move in December.The Fed rate-hike buzz is a headwind and a tailwind for bank stocks. Rate hikes would probably help banks boost net interest margins. But with the general market selling off, it's hard for financials to advance.IBD'S TAKE: Bank earnings are long gone, but Fed news -- and key economic data that shift rate-hike expectations -- can give bank stocks a quick boost or cut them off. If you're holding financial stocks or ETFs heading into the Fed policy meeting on Sept. 20-21, consider this risk-limiting earnings options strategy.Superregional bank SunTrust Banks (STI), meanwhile, has flirted with a 44.29 buy point over the past week or so, and ended Friday trades down 1.1% to 43.39. Great Western Bancorp (GWB), meanwhile, faded from a 35.01 entry by dropping 0.7% to 32.03, but was still trading within a flat base pattern.Citigroup (C), Bank of America (BAC), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Morgan Stanley (MS) were not within buy range. Citigroup is facing resistance at the 48 price range.Bank of America fell fractionally to end the day at 15.74. Citigroup dropped 1.3% to 47.17 while Morgan Stanley lost 1.4% to 31.59, while Goldman Sachs lost 1.8% to 168.57. Wells Fargo (WFC) slid by 2.4% to 48.72, dropping below its 200-day line.Wells Fargo on Thursday agreed to pay a $185 million fine after authorities said 5,300 workers surreptitiously opened credit-card and deposit accounts in customers' names in a scheme to juice sales numbers. Wells has fired those workers.RELATED:Big Bank Stocks Are Leading, But Only This One Is A Buy NowDow Nears Key Support; Are Bank Stocks Ready To Lead?Fed's Yellen, Fischer Send Mixed Messages, Leave Markets Guessing

Bank stocks like JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) have rallied over the past week as Federal Reserve officials expressed more openness to an interest-rate hike, but are any of them buys right now? Just one.JPMorgan erased intraday losses to closed uncahnged at 67.50 on the stock market today, still in range after clearing a 66.58 buy point on Monday from handle in a consolidation. Volume on the breakout was barely average, not a great sign. A stock is considered within buying range if it is 5% or less above a buy point.Super regional SunTrust Banks (STI) and Great Western Bancorp (GWB), meanwhile, are basing and are near buy points.SunTrust rallied to close up 0.2% to 44.07 Wednesday, just below a 44.29 entry area. Great Western finished 0.3% higher at 34.24 as it makes its way through a flat base with a 35.11 entry.TD (TD), meanwhile, was carving its way through a flat base with a 45.84 buy point. TD fell 0.5% to 44.60 Wednesday.IBD'S TAKE: Bank earnings are long gone, but Fed news -- and key economic data that shift rate hike expectations -- can give bank stocks a quick boost or cut them off. Pay attention to Friday's jobs report. And if you're holding financial stocks or ETFs, consider this risk-limiting earnings options strategy.Meanwhile, Bank of America, Citigroup, Wells Fargo (WFC), Goldman Sachs (GS) and Morgan Stanley (MS) are showing some constructive action, but are far from a proper buy zone.Bank of America lost 0.3% but is building the right side of a deep base, with strong gains since clearing its 200-day line on Aug. 5. Citigroup also fell 0.3% with Morgan Stanley down 0.45. Goldman Sachs rose 9 cents to 169.46 while Wells Fargo closed 0.4% higher.RELATED:Are Bank Stocks Ready To Lead?Stock Market Today Video: Stocks Dip As Oil Lags; Salesforce Slides On Results, Veeva SoarsFed's Yellen, Fischer Send Mixed Messages, Leave Markets Guessing7 Tips For Reducing Your Monthly Home-Mortgage Costs

Stocks eased at the open Wednesday, but top new growth stock Veeva Systems (VEEV) burst into new high ground following Wall Street-beating Q2 results reported late Tuesday. Bank stocks also rallied.The supplier of business software to the pharmaceutical and biotech industry jumped more than 10% to 41.57, striking new highs in the process after Tuesday's 3% drop. During that session, the stock received vital support at the key 10-week moving average.The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.2%. The big-cap and megacap gauge looks poised to end slightly down for the month of August, where it started at 18,432.The Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 also fell less than 0.2% following a lower-than-expected reading on the Chicago PMI survey, which at 51.5 for August still showed that business is expanding in the Chicago area. Econoday had expected a 55.2 reading.Veeva, which joined IBD Leaderboard as a top-flight growth stock on June 20 near 34, has now rallied nearly 50% since initially breaking out of a first-stage cup with handle base at 28.05. Many of the biggest stock market winners built this pattern en route to outstanding gains. Veeva's profit in the July-ended second quarter lifted 15% to 15 cents a share, smashing Wall Street's view for zero growth.While the 15% jump in earnings per share was the smallest increase since early 2014, Veeva has now averaged 47% EPS growth over the past six quarters. The company, which went public in October 2013, reflects how newer companies tend to take over as new market winners.An intrepid investor could have bought a small position when the stock pulled back to or near its 10-week moving average both in late June (near 31.42) and on Tuesday ahead of results (near 38.09).IBD's TAKE: To find great stocks, first size up their strength in terms of profits, sales, margins, return on equity, relative stock strength, relative group strength, level of fund sponsorship and solid chart action that shows huge demand vs. available supply. A great place to begin your growth stock research is by using IBD Stock Checkup, found in the Research section at Investors.com.Elsewhere in the stock market today, banks continued to rise amid growing anticipation that the Federal Reserve will follow through on its pledge to raise interest rates. Goldman Sachs (GS) bobbed above and below the break-even line in twice its usual volume. The investment banking titan is gunning for a fifth up day in a row. The stock has been showing bullish action lately by lifting above its long-term 200-day moving average, which is still falling. Deutsche Bank (DB) jumped more than 3% to 14.91, poised to make its highest close since late June.Healthy stocks tend to trade above the midterm 50-day moving average, which in turn is rising above the slower-moving 200-day line. So in Goldman's case, the stock needs more work building the upside of a base before a potential breakout could occur. Same goes for Apple (AAPL), which is pulling back in recent weeks following a nice upward thrust back above its 200-day moving average. Apple's rebound gained thrust with a July 27 gap up in price following slightly better than expected fiscal Q3 earnings results.Among IBD's 197 industry groups, super regional banks have been stars the past five days, up more than 4% as a group. Top stocks in that group include Great Western Bancorp (GWB) and SunTrust (STI), both of which are forming bases.

The stock market padded Tuesday's strong gains with a healthy advance by midday Wednesday. Large caps moved ahead of small caps.Meanwhile, Atlanta-based regional banking leader SunTrust Banks (STI) continued to act well after breaking out of a nearly six-month cup-with-handle pattern with a 43.13 buy point. The stock gained 2% to 44.01, up 2% past the proper entry.The Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 rose 0.8% to 0.9% each after advancing 2% and 1.4%, respectively, on Tuesday. The Dow Jones industrial average was also up 0.9%. Utilities continued to sink after having a white-hot first quarter. The Dow Jones utility average fell 0.7%. The small-cap S&P 600 added 0.6%. Volume was tracking lower on the Nasdaq from the previous session, but it was higher on the NYSE.The super regional bank and money center bank industry subgroups held a spot among the top 15 advancers among IBD's 197 industry groups in the stock market today, each rising more than 2% so far. The growing prospect of another rate hike at either the June or July Federal Reserve meetings has apparently attracted more institutional buying in lenders. Higher short-term interest rates will enable banks to charge more for loans, improving profit margins.SunTrust suffered mightily in the wake of the subprime debt crash, as the bank suffered net losses in both 2009 and 2010, but earnings have since gotten back on track. Wall Street sees EPS rising in the low- to mid-single digits both this year and next. Pretax margin has risen sharply over the past five years, from 0.2% in 2010 to 31.5% last year. It has total assets of $194 billion as of March this year. Non-performing loans represented just 0.7% of total loans outstanding. A quarter-to-quarter increase of $303 million in such loans was due mainly to Wall Street downgrades of energy-related debt.SunTrust gets an 82 Earnings Per Share Rating from IBD Stock Checkup. Just two other companies in its Banks-Super Regional subgroup get a higher EPS Rating: Great Western Bancorp (GWB) (92) and Regions Financial (RF) of Birmingham, Ala. (86).The 5% buy zone in SunTrust extends up to 45.29.Which commercial and real estate-focused bank joined IBD Leaderboard as a premium growth play that just also broke out? See it here.Elsewhere in the market Wednesday, various oil-related stocks advanced, as West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures headed toward the $50-a-barrel level.Drilling, field services and oil machinery subgroups paced the upside with gains of 2.7% to 3.3%. The field services is ranked highest among the three at 100th among 197 IBD groups and subgroups, as seen in IBD's daily rankings. In the group, 800-pound industry gorilla Halliburton (HAL) (EPS 8, Relative Strength Rating 84) gained more than 2.5% in light trade to 42.53 and was looking to clear a 42.92 handle buy point in a very deep, cup-style bottoming base.Oil States (OIS), Superior Energy Services (SPN), Archrock Partners (APLP), RPC Inc. (RES) and USA Compression (USAC) are the only other Halliburton group peers that hold an RS Rating of 80 or higher and trade at least 10 a share.

Stocks fell sharply in the first 45 minutes of trading Friday, as investors frowned upon the huge miss in May U.S. payrolls, up a mere 38,000 vs. the consensus forecast for 158,000 net new jobs. Banks led the sell-off, but utility stocks rallied.The Nasdaq composite sank more than 1.1%; the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average each fell 0.7% to 0.8%. Dow industrials component JPMorgan Chase (JPM) dropped more than 3%, and fellow Dow member Goldman Sachs (GS) lost almost 3%. The former has been working on the right side of a new base since mid-February; the latter is still nearly 30% below a 52-week high of 218.77.The Dow utility average rebounded 1.3% and looked poised to register a second straight weekly gain.Also bucking the decline were chipmakers. The Philly SOX index gained more than 0.2% early before giving back virtually all of that advance on the back of strong quarterly results from large-cap play Broadcom (AVGO).The leading chipmaker and chip design firm for various markets gapped up at the open and gushed 5% higher to 162.89, moving past a 159.75 base-on-base buy point. The stock has made an excellent run since clearing a first-stage base at 39.84 in September 2013. Yet Friday's breakout was from a first-stage base. In August 2015, Broadcom undercut the low of a prior cup base that formed from late March to late May of the same year. That correction reset Broadcom's base count.Broadcom posted a 26% gain in earnings to $2.69 a share in the April-ended fiscal second quarter, beating Wall Street's view by 13%. Revenue leapt 119% to $3.54 billion, reflecting the merger between Broadcom and Avago Technologies. The huge top-line increase stopped a four-quarter streak of decelerating sales growth from 131% (Q1 of FY 2015) to 8% (Q1 of the current fiscal year).Fresh economic data that followed the weak jobs report on Friday appeared to confirm the slow pace of economic growth, with the ISM services index coming in at 52.9 for May, below Econoday's forecast of 55.5. A figure above 50 indicates expansion. April factory orders rose 1.9%, just missing the 2.0% growth view.Separately, the Markit PMI survey declined to 51.3 in May vs. 52.8 in April. A strike among Verizon (VZ) workers likely contributed to the small increase in May U.S. payrolls.A few leading stocks are trying to keep their breakouts intact. Fast-growing retail chain Five Below (FIVE) rose 1% to 43.32. It's just below a 43.52 base-on-base entry.SunTrust Banks (STI) slid 4% to 42.35, 1% below a 43.13 cup-with-handle buy point. Volume was running sharply above normal pace for both stocks.Among IBD 50 names in the stock market today, WebMD (WBMD) was one of the hardest hit, falling more than 2% to 64.20. The health information website, ranked No. 6 in the current list, closed a $360 million convertible debt offering earlier this week, which ultimately could dilute the company's share count. WebMD still has a relatively small supply of stock, with 39 million shares outstanding and a float of 35 million.The stock has made a strong run since breaking out of a cup-with-handle pattern at 46.01 in early December.As seen in Thursday's Big Picture column and Market Pulse table, the market is currently in a confirmed uptrend. This means an investor has a higher probability of making money when buying breakouts of high-quality growth stocks at proper buy points.Is your stock is best in class within its industry group in terms of profit growth, margins, sales, return on equity, institutional fund sponsorship and relative price strength? Check it out at Investors.com's exclusive tool, IBD Stock Checkup.

Mkts went into reverse yesterday.....as earnings seasons moves on and investors/traders struggle with how overvalued/overbought the mkt is based on broader macro economic conditions and very mixed earnings reports - ...the dollar ended the day higher sending oil and other commodities lower as investors reconsider the prospect of higher rates here in the US when the FED meets next week. Once again - many are left asking - Could the FED surprise the mkts and hike in April? Let me be clear - in the words of Luis Enrique - "Yo no se manana..." (I don't know about tomorrow)...but I do know that today - the answer to that question is NO WAY!Once again - you got some of the talking heads suggesting that the US economy is so strong that rates need to rise sooner rather than later - the most recent Hawk is Eric Rosengren - Boston's Fed President as he re-iterated 'his' opinion on Monday that the FED'was closer to raising rates than many investors anticipate.... and that the mkt may be underestimating the FED's pace of tightening'Ok sports fans - here we go again.....all the talk of the next FED move just days ahead of their meeting and the end of the month..... Now while I believe that we won't get a move in April - I do expect the FED to leave the door wide open for the June hike (as expected). To add fuel to that fire we heard from Peter Gorra - head of FX trading at BNP Paribas......(Forex - FX - trading is defined as the global decentralized mkt for the trading of currencies - buying, selling and exchanging them at current prices). Currencies are very sensitive to any move in rates so - Peter does sit at the center of speculation.....and he thinks that"U.S. data has actually been pretty good, and there is very little chance of a June move by the Fed priced in,"Ok - first - US data has been pretty good? Really? Let me count thy ways:Yesterday's Philly Fed report - big disappointment, Earlier in this month alone we learned that ISM NY - disappointed, Empire State Manf - disappointed, labor mkt conditions - disappointed, Factory orders - disappointed, Factory orders ex Transports - disappointed, Durable Goods - disappointed, Durables Ex transports -disappointed, Wholesale inventories - disappointed, Wholesale trade - disappointed, Retail Sales - a big disappointment, PPI - oh right - negative, PPI ex food and energy - negative, Construction Spending - negative, Industrial production - another negative.....but so much for the negatives...lets accentuate the positives shall we?Non Farm payrolls - met expectations in terms of 'jobs created' - never mind that they are low wage, temporary (let's ignore that fact), and forget the fact that layoffs hit a 6 month high in January with daily headlines of more 'restructurings' (layoffs) as we move thru earnings season.... US Markit ISM met expectations (positive), ISM Manf -beat, ISM Prices Paid - beat, Oh and the Univ of Mich sentiment survey was 'better than expected', and Earnings reports - yeah - they are missing top line organic growth, yet still beating embarrassingly low earnings estimates - but hey - a beat is a beat and that is positive...so maybe Pete is on the right track.....But as far as the mkt NOT pricing in a June hike - I would disagree - the FED has been quite clear on that point...she has left the June door wide open - if investors have not heard that call of the wild - then they are living under a rock.....Now the real question is not if they have heard the call - the question is Do they believe the call? And that is up for discussion - because here is where I do agree with Peter.....if investors do not believe her and ignore the calls for higher rates and then she in fact moves on rates - then he is right - investors will scream - what the ...?Given Yellen's clear dovish stance, the mkts are not looking for any rate hike this month at all, but we are seeing a small pullback - which reflects just a bit of 'uncertainty' as some investors/traders recede to the sidelines.....but then I expect that next week we will get the usual ramp up when it is clear that rates will go nowhere. Look - the Fed is worried about the both the US and the global economies and feels a bit trapped...... So - next week expect more 'nothing done'.Yesterday's ECB press conference doesn't help.....He (Mario Draghi) did nothing in terms of another policy move but did leave the door open to further negative interest-rate cuts....oh...and that is another sure sign of 'strength'! This morning we wake up to the latest Japanese headline - Hold on this one is good....."BoJ Officials Are Said to Eye Possible Negative Rates on Loans" - Yes - you read that correctly.....the headline suggests that the BoJ may consider offering NEGATIVE rates on some loans (in addition the negative rates on deposits) in order to stimulate their economy....... So the bank will pay YOU to borrow money to invest......Does the word 'desperation' come to mind at all?This morning US futures are once again hovering around the unchanged line...initially lower by 3 pts in early trading - but have now recovered a bit and are slightly positive at 7 am. There are no economic reports today to speak of , but we will get another slew of earnings....Caterpillar (CAT)and McDonald's (MCD) will hit the tape prior to the opening while Alcoa (AA), Kimberly-Clark (KMB), Sun Trust (STI) report post close. Traders will now get a chance to react to last nights announcements from Alphabet (GOOGL) and General Electric (GE)...Alphabet missed on both the top and the bottom line (that was surprising) - the stock sold off 5% in the moments after the announcement and are trading at $722/sh right now.GE on the other hand beat the estimates but is also seeing some profit taking in their stock in early morning trading. Trading at $30.65 down 0.30 cts.As we approach the end of April you would expect to see is a narrowing of market breadth and this is exactly what we are currently seeing. The S&P is testing the November 2015 highs (just over 2100) and hitting a wall......Relative Strength (RSI) which began to roll over in March is suggesting market breadth is narrowing or that fewer and fewer stocks are holding up the indexes as money moves into the largest blue chip companies (think safety) typical of what you would see ahead of an expected correction.Now that being said - there are so many other things to consider......The Fed and the fact that we are in a Presidential election year.....and we are in the 8th year of the current presidency... and historically, the mkts tend to peak in April and then suffer for the rest of the year.Since 1900, the S&P has on average, fallen by 1.2% in the 8th year of a presidential term, with the market rising only 44 percent of the time. This summer will be very interesting.....History shows us (82% if the time) that if stocks rise between July 31 and October 31, then we can expect the incumbent party to win in November (Think Hillary).....BUT If stocks fall, (86% of the time) then the thinking is that a new party will take over. (Think Trump) ....so will history repeat itself or not?I expect the mkt to continue to churn and challenge resistance right here at 2100........I do not expect any major move in either direction until next week's FED announcement. Remember - it is also month end - so expect some window dressing as we move thru next week.
Take good care. Have a great weekend.Take Good Care

Apple's (AAPL) stock price initially shot up Tuesday following an analyst upgrade while megabanks Bank of America (BAC) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) also received positive marks.

Apple was upgraded to outperform by Wells Fargo, which said a recent correction in shares has gone too far. The iPhone and iPad maker's share price spiked as much as 8% after the open in the stock market today but closed up just 0.6% as the overall market staged a sudden, late reversal.
On Monday, Apple shares sank as much as 13% to 92 intraday before closing down 2.5% to 103.12, amid an overall market sell-off over fears about China's economy.

Bank of America's stock price popped as high as 6% after it was upgraded by Bernstein, Macquarie Research and Baird, but finished 0.2% lower. That followed Monday's upgrade of BofA by Keefe Bruyette & Woods.
BofA was one of several banks to receive upgrades on Tuesday. Others include JPMorgan, SunTrust Banks (STI) and Barclays (BCS). JPMorgan shares closed down 0.6%.
Adobe Systems (ADBE) saw its stock price jump after it was upgraded to outperform from neutral by Baird and given an 85 price target. But Adobe ended up just 0.4%.
Shares of apparel retailer American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) rallied 2% after it was upgraded to outperform from market perform by FBR Capital.

GPS systems maker Garmin (GRMN) saw its stock price dip 0.8% despite an upgrade by Raymond James, while shares of logistical service provider Expeditors International (EXPD) climbed 1.6% after it was upgraded to buy by Stifel Nicolaus.Apple's (AAPL) stock price initially shot up Tuesday following an analyst upgrade while megabanks Bank of America (BAC) and JPMorgan Chase (JPM) also received positive marks.Apple was upgraded to outperform by Wells Fargo, which said a recent correction in shares has gone too far. Bank stocks have been rallying amid an improving economy and the expectation of higher interest rates, but will the rally continue when second-quarter results start filtering in during July?Financial services specialist Keefe, Bruyette & Woods expects a "challenging" second quarter for the big money-center banks amid margin pressures and lower-than-expected trading revenue.As for large regional banks: KBW notes that Wall Street analysts expect residential-mortgage and credit-card balances to rebound in the second quarter, helping to drive commercial and consumer loan growth.Still, KBW analysts expect continued net interest margin compression in the sector.In its second-quarter preview of bank stocks, Deutsche Bank research analysts see "less upside in the near term," given that the big money-center bank stocks have "rallied nicely" since last July.So what are their top bank-stock picks?Deutsche Bank's top names among the biggest bank stocks are JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Bank of America (BAC).The former's net interest margin "may positively surprise," Deutsche Bank said, and JPMorgan Chase might also have lower expenses and a decent return on capital.Cost cuts will also likely impact Bank of America positively, the analysts noted. Their "buy" rating also reflects "large leverage to higher interest rates" and reduced concerns over capital levels.Among the large regional banks, both Deutsche Bank and KBW give high ratings to Atlanta-based SunTrust Banks (STI) as it continues to better manage expenses and its balance sheet.KBW cites SunTrust, Northern Trust (NTRS) and Zions Bancorp (ZION) as the three big regional banks likely to beat Wall Street earnings estimates in Q2.IBD also rates Northern Trust highly, with a Composite Rating of 87 out of a possible 99. Zions has an 80 score, SunTrust a 78 and JPMorgan a 75.Deutsche Bank also has a buy rating on Buffalo, NY-based M&T Bank (MTB) ahead of a long-awaited deal to acquire Hudson City Bancorp (HCBK), which it expects to occur later this year.
Stock futures remained mixed, but were improving slightly ahead of Friday's open.

Dow futures were down 28.3 points, trading above their hour-earlier lows. Nasdaq 100 futures were up 31.8 points. S&P 500 futures climbed out of negative territory to trade a fraction above the break-even line. Small Caps also looked positive, with Russell 2000 futures up about 1 point.

The stock market today starts trade with Nasdaq pressed flat against its June 24 high, and the S&P 500 less than 0.5% from its May 20 high-water mark. The week's solid-volume gains have been positive, suggesting institutional buying and posting a fresh banner over the market's status. The eurozone's detente with Greece, a positive week on China's markets, a healthy advance by the dollar and a positive launch to the second-quarter earnings season have all helped buoy investor optimism. But the Nasdaq has briefly topped, then reversed below highs several times since March, leaving the market frustrated in a narrow trading range.

Economic news was generally positive early Friday, with consumer prices ticking up 0.3% in June, the Labor Department reported. The increase was slightly less than May's 0.4% rise, but precisely in line with economist consensus projections. Core consumer prices, minus energy and food, gained 0.2% — up from 0.1% in May and also right in line with expectations.

Housing starts surprised, jumping nearly 10% to an annualized rate of 1.174 million in June. The Commerce Department revised its May estimate higher and said building permits increased to a pace of 1.343 million vs. 1.250 million permits issued in May. Both numbers were comfortably above consensus projections.

In stocks, there was no shortage of big names in motion ahead of Friday's open, nearly all stirred by quarterly results. Oilfield service big dog Schlumberger (SLB) andGeneral Electric (GE) edged up 1% each. SunTrust Banks (STI) rolled ahead 2%. Chipmaker Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) and Swedish telecom heavy Ericsson (ERIC) surged 5% apiece.

Google (GOOGL) lit the afterburners, keeping the 13% after-hours gain that followed its second-quarter results late Thursday. Revenue powered up 14% and earnings jumped 15% year over year while cost increases slowed to 10% from 13% in Q1. Lower legal expenses were key, the company said. Growth in paid clicks to ads also slowed, to 18% vs. 25% a year ago. Google cleared a 584.80 buy point on Tuesday and ended Thursday 2.9% above that buy marker.

Rental car leader Hertz Global (HTZ) spiked 13% after announcing it restated two years of financial results, was set to spin off its equipment rental operations and expected to reach $300 million in cost savings before year-end. The company said it would spin off the equipment rental arm in the second quarter of 2016 and announced a $1 billion share repurchase initiative. Hertz shares ended Thursday 46% below their August 2014 high.

SolarWinds (SWI) caught a downdraft, diving 11% before the open. The Austin, Texas-based software developer reported second-quarter earnings above and revenue below consensus estimates. Management guided Q3 expectations to a similar end: with earnings above, revenue below current projections. The stock has gradually been winding down from a December high.
On the IBD 50 list, most of the group was flat ahead of the open. Facebook (FB) rose 2% to lead the list. The social networking juggernaut ended Thursday 2% above an 86.17 flat-base buy point.

Overseas, China's markets capped the week on a positive note. The Shanghai Composite popped 3.5% Friday, leaving it ahead 2% for the week. Hong Kong's Hang Seng index gained 1%, also notching a weekly advance of 2%. In Japan, Tokyo's Nikkei 225 crept up 0.3% on Friday, finishing the week with a 4.4% gain, aided by the rising dollar.
Europe's leading indexes were tightly mixed at midday, tracking toward healthy weekly gains, with the CAC-40 in Paris up more than 4% and Frankfurt's DAX trading up over 3% vs. last Friday's close.

The dollar eased against the euro and the yen, pulling back from Thursday's seven-week high vs. the euro. Oil prices didn't move much, with West Texas Intermediate down a fraction, but 3.5% lower for the week — following the prior week's 7.3% dive. Brent crude traded a fraction higher Friday and down 2.6% for the week. Natural gas rose 1%, putting it more than 4% above last Friday's settle price. Gold dropped a few pennies, trading down 1.2% for the week.Stock futures remained mixed, but were improving slightly ahead of Friday's open.Dow futures were down 28.3 points, trading above their hour-earlier lows. Nasdaq 100 futures were up 31.8 points. S&P 500 futures climbed out of negative territory to trade a fraction above the break-even line. Small Caps also looked positive, with Russell 2000 futures up about 1 point.The stock market today starts trade with Nasdaq pressed flat against its June 24 high, and the S&P 500 less than 0.5% from its May 20 high-water mark. The week's solid-volume gains have been positive, suggesting institutional buying and posting a fresh banner over the market's status. The eurozone's detente with Greece, a positive week on China's markets, a healthy advance by the dollar and a positive launch to the second-quarter earnings season have all helped buoy investor optimism. The small-cap stock first cleared a 28.27 buy point Wednesday and then dipped under the entry Thursday. Several stocks in the group were threatening to cross buy points, including SunTrust Banks (STI), Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB) and BB&T (BBT). All but three of the 31 big banks examined by the Federal Reserve won approval of any plans to return capital to investors in the second round of annual stress tests. In other words: more payouts for shareholders.

The U.S. units of Spain's Banco Santander (SAN) and Germany's Deutsche Bank (DB) failed round 2 of the Fed's stress tests, while the Fed ordered Bank of America  (BAC) to resubmit its capital plan by the end of the third quarter.
It's the second straight year Santander failed the test. And the Fed cited "numerous and significant deficiencies" in Deutsche Bank's capital planning.
Meanwhile, Wells Fargo (WFC) and Morgan Stanley (MS) boosted their dividends and Morgan approved a new buyback plan, joining other banks that received the Fed's OK of their capital plans.
Shares of BofA fell 1% late, while Morgan Stanley rose 2% and Wells Fargo edged up 0.1%.

The second round of the exams — the Comprehensive Capital Analysis and Review (CCAR) — is more stringent than round one, the Dodd-Frank Act Stress Tests (DFAST), because it examines banks' abilities to pay dividends, buy back shares and still serve borrowers during times of severe economic distress.

This year, the Fed examined 31 banks, each with assets exceeding $50 billion. All 31 banks passed DFAST last week, which means they met the Fed's minimum capital requirements. It was the first time they all passed since the test's 2009 inception.
A More Likely Place To Trip

Round 2 is where banks are more likely to stumble. Michael Corbat, the CEO of Citigroup (C), should be breathing easier, since the New York-based lender passed this year's tests after failing two out of the last three years. Last year's failure resulted in Citi's selling overseas branches as well as selling its consumer finance unit, OneMain Financial, for $4.25 billion.

This is the first year Citigroup will be able to boost its dividend since the financial crisis. Corbat and Chief Financial Officer John Gerspach's jobs reportedly were on the line during this year's stress tests. Citi's passage comes as a big win for them. Citi shares rose 3.7% in after-hours trading.
HSBC (HSBC) and Zions Bancorp (ZION) failed last year's CCAR but passed this year's exam.
Goldman Sachs (GS), JPMorgan Chase (JPM) and Morgan Stanley met minimum capital requirements on a post-test basis after submitting adjustments.

"This is becoming less and less an adversarial process between the organizations," said Ernest Patrikis, a former New York Fed official now with the White & Case law firm. "I think for the banking system as a whole, we should feel a bit better."
Musing Over Board Control

While CCAR has become the key test of banks' health since the Great Recession, Patrikis said he'd like to see the day when a bank's board — not the Fed — again has the power to return money to owners. "Banks should be allowed to have more freedom to raise dividends," he said.

In addition to the banks listed above, the Federal Reserve had no objections to the plans of Ally Financial (ALLY), American Express (AXP), Bank of New York Mellon (BK), BB&T (BBT), BBVA Compass (BBVA), Bank of Montreal Quebec (BMO), Capital One Financial (COF), Citizens Financial Group (CFG), Comerica (CMA), Discover Financial Services (DFS), Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB), Huntington Bancshares (HBAN), Keycorp (KEY), M&T Bank (MTB), MUFG Americas Holdings (MTU), Northern Trust (NTRS), PNC Financial Services (PNC), Regions Financial (RF), State Street (STT), SunTrust Banks (STI) and U.S. Bancorp (USB).All but three of the 31 big banks examined by the Federal Reserve won approval of any plans to return capital to investors in the second round of annual stress tests. Shares of regional banks Comerica (CMA), PNC Financial Services (PNC) and SunTrust Banks (STI) all rose Friday after they reported fourth-quarter results that reflected a continued U.S. economic rebound and a sturdier credit environment.

But a useful measure of profitability, net interest margins — the difference between the interest that banks pay on deposits and the interest that they collect from borrowers — was still down for all three, a reflection of the cellar-level interest rates that continue to challenge the industry.

Comerica reported Q4 earnings per share up 3 cents from last year to 80 cents, topping analyst forecasts for 76 cents. Revenue rose 0.9% to $640 million, also beating views. The profit gain was hampered by what the company characterized as a low-rate environment plus technology and regulatory expenses. Comerica's net interest margin during the quarter also fell to 2.57% from 2.86% in the same period last year.

Loans and deposits for the Dallas-based bank both rose slightly from the year-earlier quarter, and money reserved for credit losses fell. The bank put Q4 average total loans at $47.4 billion, up 7% from a year earlier.
Q4 deposits rose 9% to $57.8 billion.
Share repurchases during the quarter helped the bottom line.
"While we continue to manage headwinds, including the low-rate environment as well as rising technology and regulatory expenses, we remain focused on the long term," CEO Ralph Babb said.

Comerica stock was down about 0.4% to 40.81 by late afternoon but was as high as 44.80 earlier in the stock market today, Friday. The stock has spent the past 12 days below its 50-day moving average, amid broader trading volatility.
However, the plummeting oil prices that have compounded that volatility have not hurt Comerica, Babb says.

"Given that the significant decline in oil and gas prices has only materialized in the past couple of months and our customers are generally well hedged, we have not yet seen adverse trends in the portfolio," he said. "We continue to closely monitor the total portfolio, as well as the energy sector and any residual impacts on the Texas economy."

For 2015, the company guided for loan growth roughly equal to last year's, "relatively stable" net interest and noninterest income, a higher provision for credit losses and higher noninterest expenses due to an increase in regulatory, technology and pension costs.
Pittsburgh-based PNC, the nation's second biggest regional bank, said that its Q4 EPS fell 3 cents to $1.84. Revenue was down fractionally to around $4 billion, edging views.

But commercial loans continued to rise, jumping nearly 10% to $128.4 billion during the quarter. And the money reserved for credit losses fell by 54% from last year to $52 million as credit quality remained stable.
The bank's net interest margin fell to 2.89%, down from 3.38% in Q4 2013, partly reflecting lower loan yields.
Loans grew by 5% or $9 billion from Q4 last year to $205 billion. Credit quality remained stable, PNC said. Deposits also grew 5%, to $232 billion.
Shares of PNC were trading up 1.2% to 83.47 by late afternoon Friday after a five-day streak of declines.

"We added customers, grew loans and deposits, increased fee income and capital, and reduced expenses," CEO William Demchak said. "While the near-term revenue environment remains challenging, I like how we are positioned heading into 2015."

Atlanta-based SunTrust Banks reported fourth-quarter EPS that fell 5 cents from the year-earlier period to 72 cents, missing views for 80 cents. Revenue inched down from a year ago to $2.043 billion, just below views for $2.045 billion. But revenue was up from the third quarter, led by mortgages and investment banking, the company said.
And SunTrust was able to grow average performing loans by 6% during the year to $132.7 billion. Deposits grew 7% by Dec. 31 to $136.9 billion.
"Our strong performance in the fourth quarter and 2014 was driven by good loan and deposit growth, continued expense discipline and improved credit quality," CEO William H. Rogers said.
The bank's net interest margin fell to 2.96% during the quarter from 3.20% in 2013.

Stocks fell Thursday and ended near their session lows amid rate-hike fears and lower oil prices. The S&P 500 and the the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 1.4% each. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq lost 1.2%. Volume rose on both major exchanges in the stock market today, according to preliminary data.
Crude oil dropped nearly 3% to settle at $41.75 a barrel, the lowest close in more than two months.

After the close, networking giant Cisco Systems (CSCO) lost 2% as a weak outlook for the current quarter offset better-than-expected fiscal Q1 results. It posted earnings of 59 cents a share on sales of $12.68 billion. Views were for earnings of 56 cents a share on revenue of $12.65 billion. But it expects second-quarter revenue to be flat to 2% higher.

In the regular session, Maximus (MMS) ended off its session low, but still plunged 22% after gapping lower on disappointing quarterly sales and weak outlook. Before the open, the provider of consulting services reported fiscal Q4 earnings of 53 cents a share, or a penny above views. Sales came in at $578.7 million vs. views of $591.02 million. Maximus pegged 2016 earnings at $2.40 to $2.70 a share vs. views for $2.95 a share. Intraday, the stock triggered the 8% sell rule from a 69.34 buy point in a cup-with-handle base.

Advance Auto Parts (AAP) gapped below its 50-day line and slumped 13% after missing views and lowering guidance. The stock fell more than 8% below a 192.37 entry in a consolidation. It also breached support at its 200-day moving average. The retailer also announced that CEO Darren Jackson will retire after eight years on the job.

Leaders up in volume were few, but NetEase (NTES) gapped up and rallied 2% in reaction to its stellar Q3 results from late Tuesday. The Chinese gaming firm's earnings jumped 56%, while sales more than doubled. The stock cleared a buy point of 154.98.

Tal Education Group (XRS) added nearly 3% to a second straight new high. It's now almost 6% past a 38.75 buy point from a consolidation. The Chinese for-profit school operator was recently featured in IBD Industry Themes.
Reports on producer prices, retail sales, consumer sentiment and business inventories will be out Friday morning. Cleveland Fed President Loretta Mester will be speaking.
Retailer J.C. Penney (JCP) and fire and security products maker Tyco International (TYC) will report earnings Friday.
